elements.name: deceasedIntroExplanation
elements.title:
First, this service will ask about the person who died. All the questions revolve around them. This service will ask about you, the applicant(s), in a later step.

Use the information from their death certificate to help you answer some of the questions.

elements.name: deceasedName
elements.title: What is the name of the person who died?
elements.description: This is the spelling that you want on the Representation Grant for the person who died.

elements.name: deceasedNameFAQ1
elements.title: What if the {deceasedName} used more than one spelling or version of their name?
elements.body: This service will ask you for other spellings of {deceasedName}'s name in a later step. This includes different versions, for example, leaving out their middle names.

elements.name: deceasedNameFAQ2
elements.title: What if {deceasedName}'s name is originally in a different language?
elements.body: You will need to write the English translation of {deceasedName}'s name. Supreme Court of British Columbia forms need to be completed in the English language.

elements.name: deceasedNameReplace
elements.title: Would you like this service to replace {deceasedName}'s name with a nickname?
elements.description: This nickname is only to make your experience with this service more personalized. This nickname will not appear on the Representation Grant.

elements.name: deceasedNickname
elements.title: What is the nickname you would like to see instead of {deceasedName}?
elements.description: You can use anything you like, for example, "your husband" or "Uncle Guy" or "Cousin Nereid". You can always come back to change this at any time.

elements.name: deceasedDateOfDeath
elements.title: What is the date of death on {deceasedName}'s death certificate?

elements.name: deceasedDateOfDeathTrello
elements.title: Trello Card - Date: Set Earliest/Latest Dates

elements.name: deceasedAddress
elements.title: Where did {deceasedName} live?
elements.description: Use the address where Deceased Name spent the majority of their time.

elements.name: deceasedAddressFAQ1
elements.title: What if {deceasedName} was homeless?
elements.body: If {deceasedName} was homeless, write "no fixed address" for the street number and street name.

elements.name: deceasedAddressTrello
elements.title: Trello - Deceased Address: Add Street Address Label and Get rid of Ghost Text

elements.name: firstNations
elements.title: Was {deceasedName} a Nisga'a citizen or a member of a Treaty First Nation?

elements.name: firstNationsName
elements.title: Which of the following applied to {deceasedName}?

elements.name: firstNationsNameTrello

pages.description: We have questions about the person who died. Make sure you have the information from their death certificate to help you answer some of the questions.

elements.name: willIntroExplanation
elements.title:
Next, this service will ask if {deceasedName} made a `Will`.

If they made a Will, the following questions will check if it is valid and if there are `other testamentary documents`.

elements.name: willDiligentSearchBookmark
elements.title: Diligent Search

elements.name: willCheck
elements.title: Have you diligently searched the places where {deceasedName} would have kept important documents?
elements.description: You are responsible for making sure if {deceasedName} made a Will or not.

elements.name: willCheckFAQ1
elements.title: What is a diligent search?
elements.body:
A diligent search is checking all the places where {deceasedName} usually kept their documents.

You may not find their Will but you may find clues to where the Will is kept. The Will may be at a variety of places, including their home, their safety deposit box, or at the office of the lawyer who helped create the Will.

If you checked all the places and followed all the clues, this is considered a diligent search

If there is more than 1 applicant, the task of checking all the places can be split up between the applicants.

elements.name: willCheckYesExplanation
elements.title:
In addition to diligently searching on your own, you will also need to get a "Search of Wills Notice". You do not need to get this right away to continue with this service, but you will eventually need to provide the results.

You get a "Search of Wills Notice" from the [link?] Vital Statistics Agency of British Columbia. If {deceasedName} registered a Will, the "Search of Wills Notice" will have information about the location of the Will.

The "Search of Wills Notice" must include a search of all of the different names and spellings that {deceasedName} used in their Will and for their assets. If you need help identifying all of the different names and spellings of the deceased, this service will guide you through that process in a later step.

elements.name: willCheckNoError
elements.title:
If you have not diligently searched yet, please do so before continuing with this service. This makes all the difference in what questions this service will ask you.

In addition to diligently searching on your own, you will also need to get a "Search of Wills Notice" and eventually provide the results.

You get a "Search of Wills Notice" from the [link?] Vital Statistics Agency of British Columbia. If {deceasedName} registered a Will, the "Search of Wills Notice" will have information about the location of the Will.

The "Search of Wills Notice" must include a search of all of the different names and spellings that {deceasedName} used in their Will and for their assets. If you need help identifying all of the different names and spellings of the deceased, this service will guide you through that process in a later step.

Option 1 is to get your old grant amended for the people applying in BC.
Option 2
Go back and say you can't use it with a reason like "not the same people applying" and apply for a new grant in BC.

elements.name: willExistsBookmark
elements.title: Will Exists

elements.name: willExists
elements.title: Did {deceasedName} make a `Will`

elements.name: willExistsFAQ1
elements.title: What if I believe {deceasedName} made a will but I/we cannot find it?
elements.body:
If you cannot confirm that a Will exists, you have to decide how you want to proceed. 

The first option is to continue searching for a Will. Do not select "Yes" to this question unless you can confirm a Will exists.

The other option is to select "No" to this question. If you discover a Will later, it can still be recognized. [???consistent language]

elements.name: willExistsFAQ2
elements.title: What if I/we don't know if the Will is valid or not?
elements.body:
If you don't know if {deceasedName}'s Will is valid or not, select "Yes". This service will ask questions to check if the Will is valid.

If necessary, this service may ask if {deceasedName} made more than one Will.

elements.name: willOtherDocExists
elements.title: Did {deceasedName} make any `other testamentary documents` or recordings?
elements.description: If {deceasedName} made an invalid Will, select "Yes" to this question.

elements.name: willOtherDocRecognize
elements.title: Do you want to have these `other testamentary documents` recognized as {deceasedName}'s `Will`?

elements.name: willOtherDocRecognizeNoReasons
elements.title:
Explain why you think each of {deceasedName}'s `other testamentary documents` are not valid or not relevant: Trello: Add Other for Pulldown or Radio
Field2: reason: radio with other. radio options: cannot find the will to which codicil relates; does not reflect deceased's final intention; working draft/draft document; unwitnessed draft; [Reminder] A copy of the testamentary document(s) is attached as an exhibit to the affidavit.
choices: will does not deal with property in BC

elements.name: willOtherDocRecognizeYesExplanation
elements.title: If you want a document with issues to be recognized, this service will ask questions to identify the issues.

elements.name: question155
elements.title: Multiple Wills

elements.name: willMultiple
elements.title: Did {deceasedName} make more than one Will?
elements.description: This includes making a new Will to replace an older one.

elements.name: willMultipleFAQ1
elements.title: Do I/we include `other testamentary documents`?
elements.body:
No. This question is only about the Will.

If {deceasedName} made a `codicil` or `other testamentary documents`, this service will ask about those documents later.

elements.name: willRevoked
elements.title: Did {deceasedName}'s latest Will replace their older Wills?
elements.description: Look at the will. Usually at the beginning. "This is the last will and revokes/replaces all previous wills" or similar wording.

elements.name: willRevokedYesExplanation
elements.title:
If {deceasedName} made a new Will that replaced an older one, answer the following questions using information from the most recent Will. If their most recent Will is valid, you will not need to answer questions about old Wills.

If {deceasedName}'s most recent Will has any issues, this service may ask about their next most recent Will.

elements.name: willDifferentAssets
elements.title: Did {deceasedName} make more than one `Will` that each deal with different `assets`

elements.name: willDifferentAssetsNoExplanation
elements.title:
[No - Super Rare]

elements.name: question187
elements.title:
Part 1: ORDER(S) SOUGHT

The petitioner(s) seek(s) the following order under section 58 (2) (a) of the Wills, Estates and Succession Act:

[indent] 1 that the attached record, document or writing represents the testamentary intentions of a deceased person

elements.name: question188
elements.title:
Part 2: FACTUAL BASIS

[Using numbered paragraphs, set out the material facts on which this petition is based.]
1
2

elements.name: question189
elements.title:
What are the facts?
(you/someone else will need support these facts with evidence such affidavits or other documents)
elements.description:
[Description]The key question is whether the document records a deliberate or fixed and final expression of intention as to the disposal of the deceased’s property on death. A deliberate or fixed and final intention is not the equivalent of an irrevocable intention, given that a will, by its nature, is revocable until the death of its maker. Rather, the intention must be fixed and final at the material time, which will vary depending on the circumstances.

[Reference: https://www.canlii.org/en/bc/bcsc/doc/2019/2019bcsc2040/2019bcsc2040.html?searchUrlHash=AAAAAQAoc2VjdGlvbiA1OCB3aWxscywgZXN0YXRlcyBhbmQgc3VjY2Vzc2lvbgAAAAAB&resultIndex=5]

elements.name: question190
elements.title:
Part 3: LEGAL BASIS
[Using numbered paragraphs, specify any rule or other enactment relied on and provide a brief summary of any other legal bases on which the petitioner(s) intend(s) to rely in support of the orders sought.] Para1 1 Section 58 of WESA empowers the court to give the relief requested. Court order curing deficiencies 58 (1)In this section, "record" includes data that (a)is recorded or stored electronically, (b)can be read by a person, and (c)is capable of reproduction in a visible form. (2)On application, the court may make an order under subsection (3) if the court determines that a record, document or writing or marking on a will or document represents (a)the testamentary intentions of a deceased person, (b)the intention of a deceased person to revoke, alter or revive a will or testamentary disposition of the deceased person, or (c)the intention of a deceased person to revoke, alter or revive a testamentary disposition contained in a document other than a will. (3)Even though the making, revocation, alteration or revival of a will does not comply with this Act, the court may, as the circumstances require, order that a record or document or writing or marking on a will or document be fully effective as though it had been made (a)as the will or part of the will of the deceased person, (b)as a revocation, alteration or revival of a will of the deceased person, or (c)as the testamentary intention of the deceased person. (4)If an alteration to a will makes a word or provision illegible and the court is satisfied that the alteration was not made in accordance with this Act, the court may reinstate the original word or provision if there is evidence to establish what the original word or provision was.

elements.name: executorIntroExplanation
elements.title: In this section, we need to figure out what rights people have to apply to manage {deceasedName}'s estate. This usually involves executors. We need to figure who is the most eligible to apply.

elements.name: executorExistsYesExplanation
elements.title:
Start by adding information about one executor at a time (if there is more than 1) Then click the "Add Executor" button to fill in information the next executor.
Add photo of button?

elements.title: yes - Follow the directions of the codicil to determine who the executors now are.

elements.name: executorCodicilNoExplanation
elements.title: no - follow the executors on the will

templateElements.name: executorName
templateElements.title: Name of the `executor` as it appears in the will.
templateElements.description:
Include the name even if some or all of the executors are not alive right now. 

Even if their name has changed since they have changed their name since that time. This service will address this later. 

Check with DDRs (What happens if the way the name is written on the will differs from the person's ID card and the document would be meaningless in practice?)

templateElements.name: executorIsCapableNoExplanation

templateElements.name: executorSpecialConditions
templateElements.title: Are there any special conditions / requirements that {deceasedName} has specified in order for {panel.executorName} to be allowed to be an executor?
templateElements.description: Example? Sometimes it might be that the executor has to wait 30 days after a primary executor dies?

templateElements.name: executorSpecialConditionsMet
templateElements.title: Have those special conditions / requirements been met?

templateElements.name: executorSpecialConditionsMetNoExplanation
templateElements.title:
no - this person will only be considered an executor if the special conditions in the will are met. this person can still apply right now under admin with will.

if you feel this special condition is discriminator (human rights violation) you can challenge this in court. court forms here.

That is all the information we need about {panel.executorName} for the moment. Continue adding more executors if there are more.
templateElements.description: no further questions for this executor. name to appear in possible-applicant list

templateElements.name: executorIsExSpouse
templateElements.title: Is {panel.executorName} an ex-spouse of {deceasedName}?
templateElements.description: Define what spouse means? Marriage like-relationship, married, etc.  Ex-spouses drop down in the hierarchy of rights if they were named as an executor if...  (Does being a primary executor AND a current spouse grant extra rights?)

templateElements.name: executorExSpouseAfterWill
templateElements.title: Was this Will (dated {willDate}) after the divorce/separation?
templateElements.description: Want to see if {deceasedName} still intended for {panel.executorName} to be an executor despite not being their spouse anymore.

templateElements.name: executorExSpouseAfterWillNoExplanation
templateElements.visibleIf: {panel.executorIsAlive} = "y" and {panel.executorIsCapable} = "y" and ({panel.executorSpecialConditions} = "n" or ({panel.executorSpecialConditions} = "y" and {panel.executorSpecialConditionsMet} = "y")) and {panel.executorIsExSpouse} = "y" and {panel.executorExSpouseAfterWill} = "n"
templateElements.title:
no - under WESA 56, ex-spouses lose their entitlement to be an executor and lose their beneficiary status and also power of appointment (to pick an executor

That is all the information we need about {panel.executorName} for the moment. Continue adding more executors if there are more.

templateElements.name: executorExSpouseAfterWillYesExplanation
templateElements.visibleIf: {panel.executorIsAlive} = "y" and {panel.executorIsCapable} = "y" and ({panel.executorSpecialConditions} = "n" or ({panel.executorSpecialConditions} = "y" and {panel.executorSpecialConditionsMet} = "y")) and {panel.executorIsExSpouse} = "y" and {panel.executorExSpouseAfterWill} = "y"
templateElements.title: yes - we will assume they were on good terms even though under WESA, ex-spouses lose their entitlement to be an executor and lose their beneficiary status.

templateElements.name: executorRenounced
templateElements.visibleIf: {panel.executorIsAlive} = "y" and {panel.executorIsCapable} = "y" and ({panel.executorSpecialConditions} = "n" or ({panel.executorSpecialConditions} = "y" and {panel.executorSpecialConditionsMet} = "y")) and ({panel.executorIsExSpouse} = "n" or ({panel.executorIsExSpouse} = "y" and {panel.executorExSpouseAfterWill} = "y" and {panel.executorExSpouseAfterWillYesExplanation} > 0))
templateElements.title: Has {panel.executorName} renounced their executorship?
templateElements.description: Renouncing executorship means they are going give up all rights they have to become an executor of 's estate. They will have to sign an affidavit and they cannot reverse their decision.  The other option, if  does not wish to be an applicant on this application but they do not want to renounce their position, they can choose not to apply but reserve their right to execute 's estate in the future.  (Might have to ask if there any other reasons the executor is not applying.)

templateElements.name: executorRenouncedFormally
templateElements.visibleIf: {panel.executorIsAlive} = "y" and {panel.executorIsCapable} = "y" and ({panel.executorSpecialConditions} = "n" or ({panel.executorSpecialConditions} = "y" and {panel.executorSpecialConditionsMet} = "y")) and ({panel.executorIsExSpouse} = "n" or ({panel.executorIsExSpouse} = "y" and {panel.executorExSpouseAfterWill} = "y")) and {panel.executorRenounced} = "y"

templateElements.title: memo - executors who renounce informally but not formally continue onto the applicant page. formal renunciations do not carry over

templateElements.name: executorRenouncedFormallyNoExplanation
templateElements.visibleIf: {panel.executorIsAlive} = "y" and {panel.executorIsCapable} = "y" and ({panel.executorSpecialConditions} = "n" or ({panel.executorSpecialConditions} = "y" and {panel.executorSpecialConditionsMet} = "y")) and ({panel.executorIsExSpouse} = "n" or ({panel.executorIsExSpouse} = "y" and {panel.executorExSpouseAfterWill} = "y")) and {panel.executorRenounced} = "y" and {panel.executorRenouncedFormally} = "n"
templateElements.title:
no - their name will still appear on the grant as rights reserved (if they are equal or higher priority than the people that get the grant)

Continue adding executors if there are more.

templateElements.name: executorRenouncedFormallyYesExplanation
templateElements.visibleIf: {panel.executorIsAlive} = "y" and {panel.executorIsCapable} = "y" and ({panel.executorSpecialConditions} = "n" or ({panel.executorSpecialConditions} = "y" and {panel.executorSpecialConditionsMet} = "y")) and ({panel.executorIsExSpouse} = "n" or ({panel.executorIsExSpouse} = "y" and {panel.executorExSpouseAfterWill} = "y")) and {panel.executorRenounced} = "y" and {panel.executorRenouncedFormally} = "y"
templateElements.title:
yes - [JIRA] click here to generate a form for them to fill out with a witness (form info already captured) We will generate a form for to renounce their executorship. It is not required to be filled out by but it will be prepared just in case they want to officially renounce their executorship.

If {panel.executorName} does not complete this form, go back to the last question and say they will not formally renounce.

That is all the information we need about {panel.executorName} for the moment. Continue adding more executors if there are more.

elements.name: spouseIntroExplanation
elements.title:
In this section, we need to figure if {deceasedName} had a `spouse`. There might be multiple spouses Will version: copy their names as they appear on the will.

Understanding Deceased Name's relatives helps identify who needs to know about how you are applying for a representation grant.

You will need to notify everyone who has a right to part of Deceased Name's estate that you are applying for a representation grant. If any of these people do not think you should manage Deceased Name's estate, they will have a fair chance tell to the court.

If you are a spouse or descendant, remember to include yourself in this step.

If you are not a relative, you'll be asked for your information later in this service.

elements.title: married and separated for less than 1? year but not yet divorced
elements.description:
better to include person than no. if you're not sure, include them. just because you are giving them notice, does not mean that you have to give them money as a beneficary.

if separated, likely not going to get anything under WESA. No noticed required. This spouse's entitlement to {deceasedName}'s belongings will be through FLA. A different court. WESA http://www.bclaws.ca/civix/document/id/lc/statreg/09013_01#section2 Family Law Act 84 http://www.bclaws.ca/civix/document/id/complete/statreg/11025_05#section84

templateElements.name: spouseDied5DaysAfter
templateElements.title: Did  die after (Deceased Date of Death + 4 days)?

templateElements.name: spouseDied5DaysAfterFAQ1
templateElements.title: Why does this date matter?
templateElements.body:
In determining who gets part of estate, it is important to know who died first. This may not sound strange, but under the law, if they died less than 5 days after Deceased Name, they are considered to have died before Deceased Name. For more information, refer to Five-day survival rule from the Wills, Estate and Succession Act (WESA).
http://www.bclaws.ca/civix/document/id/complete/statreg/00_09013_01#section10

templateElements.name: gchildDied5DaysAfterFAQ1
templateElements.title: Why does this date matter?
templateElements.body:
In determining who gets part of estate, it is important to know who died first. This may not sound strange, but under the law, if they died less than 5 days after Deceased Name, they are considered to have died before Deceased Name. For more information, refer to Five-day survival rule from the Wills, Estate and Succession Act (WESA).
http://www.bclaws.ca/civix/document/id/complete/statreg/00_09013_01#section10

Intro paragraph
pick applicants

here's a list of everyone you've identified so far. time to figure who is actually applying (applicant can be someone you haven't yet identified)
Now we need to learn more about you as the applicant.
If you are not the only applicant, we will also ask questions related to the other applicants.

elements.name: p1EarlyWillIntro
elements.title:
[Will version - custom intros GP, AWW, AGP, AGAWW, Resealing]
According the information you provided so far, your type of application is called X. Will dated. Y.

Let's first review the notice form that was filled out based on the information you provided. This notice form needs to be delivered (served) to the people and organizations you identified earlier (e.g. relatives, creditors).

When you submit your application for a representation grant, the court will need to know who you notified, and the people who delivered those notices.

We'll help you keep track and make sure you haven't missed anyone.

As part of the process to get a representation grant, you need to let the appropriate people know about your application. This means you need to deliver (serve) the following notice form to them.

People you will notify will have a ?fair? change to disagree with your applications. This gives them a fair chance ... work in 21 days... before you can file your documents to the courthouse.

elements.name: p1EarlyNoWillIntro
elements.title:
[No Will version - custom AWW, AGAWW, Resealing] Review and Deliver Notice

As part of the process to get a representation grant, you need to let the appropriate people know about your application. This means you need to deliver (serve) the following notice form to them.

Because {deceasedName} did not leave a Will (valid?), you will also need to notify anyone who {deceasedName} owed more than $10,000.

elements.name: question405
elements.title:
You're ready to deliver the P1 to people. Define served.
You will only be able to file your documents 21 days after the last person was deemed to have been served.
These are the ways you can deliver a notice. Choose the best way you see fit to notify each different person.
• In person (printer required)
• Electronically (e-mail, fax, or other electronic means) • By mail (printer required)
Here is a sample message that you can copy and paste to email people. include, ask a receipt as simply as "thanks" "I have received your email". We will provide a list of people you need to notify.

elements.name: question416
elements.title: Below is a list of people is who you need to notify and give a fair chance to disagree with your application. You may choose to notify more people than those on this list. If you do, you do not need to keep track of them.

elements.name: question408
elements.title: How did {recipient} receive notice? [for children or mentally incapable people Shawn Johnson (in the care of Taylor Johnson)]

elements.name: question409
elements.title:
Taylor Johnson sent a response acknowledging the receipt of the notice

When delivering a notice electronically, you must receive a response from the recipient before it is considered delivered.

If you haven't received a response, do a follow up first and fill in the date after you receive a confirmation of your electronic delivery.

You will retain a copy of the response and provide them when requested by the registrar
[JIRA] How best to warn applicant waiting for electronic confirmation? Should applicants move to the next page, this page would be incomplete. How are we checking for completeness?

elements.name: question406
elements.title: What if I don't get a written response when sending a notice electronically?
elements.body:
Because it is easy for people to change their contact information (such as their e-mail address of fax number), a written response is required to ensure you were able to successfully deliver your notice.



If you don't receive a response, you will have to resend the documents by mail or deliver the document to them in person.

elements.name: question399
elements.title: Why does the Public Guardian and Trustee (PGT) get a notice?
elements.body: You are required by law to notify the Public Guardian and Trustee (PGT) when a child under the age of 19 or an adult who is not mentally competent receives a gift from {deceasedName}'s estate. The PGT is there protect their interests.

elements.name: question401
elements.title:
Things to Include with Notice to Public Guardian and Trustee (PGT)

-P1
-Letter app generates
$315 in certified cheque or bank draft payable to "Public Guardian and Trustee"

elements.name: question400
elements.title:

For the minor or mentally incompetent person
• Full name
• Date of birth
• Address of where they live

For the parent/ guardian of the minor or committee of the mentally incompetent person
• Full name
• Address of where they live if they don't live with the minor/ mentally incompetent personThings to Include with Notice to Public Guardian and Trustee (PGT)

elements.description: You are responsible for knowing the requirements to serve them, including additoinal info they need and to pay the filing fee. (there may not be a filing fee).

elements.title: Did you get a written response from PGT?

elements.name: question430
elements.title: Make sure you provide a copy to the court. We'll remind you later. [In the future. Scan and upload?]

elements.name: question407
elements.title: How is the 21 days calculated?
elements.body:
Depending on how you delivered the notice, it is considered delivered
• on the date you gave the notice directly in person
• on the date you mailed the notice
• on the date you sent the notice electronically (if you receive a response)

elements.title: [JIRA] Generate P9 for each person who served a P1.

elements.name: question422
elements.title: Date the P9 was sworn by {applicantX}. occupation and address for non-applicant left blank to be filled by hand.[JIRA ability to put this off until later - applicant(s) can leave blank to swear everything at the courthouse]

elements.name: question410
elements.title:
[JIRA] Calendar/Countdown based on date of service and method of service. Tells you know when you can file.

Waiting 21 Days After the Last Notice is Delivered You must wait 21 days after delivering the last notice before you can submit your paperwork to the courts. This is to give time to the other side to receive the notice and to raise any concerns.

elements.name: question402
elements.title: I got a Notice of Dispute after I delivered my notice.
elements.body:
What happens now?
After you deliver the notice to the appropriate people and organizations, there may be some who have concerns about your application and submit a Notice of Dispute (P29). In this situation, you will not be able to get an estate grant. You may want to talk things through with the person who submitted the Notice of Dispute and see if they are willing to withdraw it. You can also apply to remove the Notice of Dispute if you believe the reason for the dispute is not valid.

Understanding land title certificates
A land title certificate contains a lot of information about a real estate. Here are some of the areas you may find useful for completing the questions. Registered Owner in Fee Simple Shows the owner(s) of the real estate. Taxation Authority

Charges, Liens and Interests
Lists any mortgages, liens or money owing on the property.
